011 the whole I should be inclined to rate the Greek of this Epistle as approaching more nearly to the standard of Classical purity than that of any other book of the N.T., with the exception perhaps of the Epistle to the Hebrews. The author of the latter has no doubt greater copiousness‚ and inore variety of construction& he is also occasionally very idiomatic‚ as in the phrase ἔμαθεν ἀφ’ ὧν ἔπαθεν v. ὃς but while the distinction between μή and οὐ 15 carefully preserved in our Epistle‚ we find in the Hebrews μή used incorrectly after ἐπεί ix. 17 ἐπεὶ μὴ τότε (al. μήποτε) ἰσχύει, ὅτε ζῇ ὁ διαθέμενος, and with the participle xi. 8 ἐξῆλθεν μὴ ἐπιστά- μενος, ver. 13 κατὰ πίστιν ἀπέθανον μὴ κομίσαντες, ver. 27 πίστει κατέλιπεν Αἴγυπτον μὴ φοβηθεὶς τὸν θυμὸν τοῦ βασιλέως (in con- trast with James i. 25). Again, the latter writer is less accurate in his use of the moods and tenses than our author.
